entry.title: Re: Single BP with Customer and Vendor roles and differen...
entry.content:
Hello @AAITIPAM ,

The answer is yes, this is completely possible and is a standard way to handle combined customer and supplier roles.

Here's how you manage the separation of the two bank accounts:

Bank Account A123: Customer Direct Debit
-Since this account is for Direct Debits (you pulling money from the customer), the payment process relies on an official agreement called a Direct Debit Mandate (like a SEPA Mandate).

-You enter Bank Account A123 on the BP master record.

-You create a Direct Debit Mandate and specifically link it to Bank Account A123.

-When you run your payment process to collect money, the system uses the details found in the active Mandate, ensuring only Bank Account A123 is used.

Bank Account B456: Supplier Direct Credit
-Since this account is for Direct Credits (you sending money to the supplier), you use a setting called the Partner Bank Type to point the payment to the correct account.

-You enter Bank Account B456 on the BP master record and assign it a unique identifier, like "B456," in the Partner Bank Type field.

-When you post the supplier's invoice, you must enter this unique identifier (B456) into the payment information on that specific invoice.

-When you run the automatic payment program, it sees the "B456" Partner Bank Type on the invoice and knows to use Bank Account B456 from the BP master data for the payment.

The Key Difference: The Customer side (A123) is controlled by the Mandate, while the Supplier side (B456) is controlled by the Partner Bank Type on the invoice. This allows both accounts to exist on the same BP, each reserved for its specific function.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: F110 : payment not possible because of reported error
entry.content:
Hello @oumouKD ,

Pl. try below options and let me know.

 

AreaDetails / ExplanationWhat to Check / Fix
Error ShownPayment run stops with generic message: “Payment not possible because of reported error.” In detailed logs: FZ 642 – Bank details of the partner with bank LU account XXXXXXXX are being used.Indicates the system found bank details that do not meet payment program requirements.
Meaning of FZ 642The bank account or bank country code ("LU" in your case) is being used but does not meet the payment method requirements, or required fields for that bank are incomplete.Fix vendor/customer bank master or payment method bank rules.
Common Causes1. Missing IBAN for LU bank2. Bank key not defined in system3. Payment method does not allow bank country LU4. Payment method does not allow foreign payments5. House bank not configured for LU destinations6. Incorrect account type (Bank account vs. IBAN mismatch)7. Paying company code not assigned fullyValidate master data + FBZP config.
Vendor/Customer Master ChecksBank account assigned under BP master may be incomplete: IBAN missing, incorrect bank key, wrong bank country.BP → Payment Transactions → Bank Details. Ensure valid LU bank key + IBAN.
FBZP – Payment Method (per Company code)Payment method may not allow payments to LU bank accounts.FBZP → Payment Methods in Company Code → Check “Country of Bank” allowed.
FBZP – Payment Method (in Country)Rules for foreign banks may be restricted (e.g., requiring IBAN/BIC).Ensure LU is not blocked. Check validations for IBAN, Bank Account No., BIC.
FBZP – Bank DeterminationHouse bank may not support payments to LU (missing bank chain/bank key relationship).Assign valid ranking order + bank account with correct currency/country.
House Bank SetupNew company code house banks might be incomplete (missing bank key for LU routing).Maintain house bank → Bank key → SWIFT → IBAN structure.
Vendor Payment DataVendor's payment method may not match the company code payment method.BP → Supplier → Payment Transactions → Ensure “payment method” matches F110 run.
Currency IssuesHouse bank does not support payment currency.Ensure bank account currency matches F110 proposal requirements.
Testing Result ObservationIntentional blocking errors appear normally → means logging works → issue occurs before payment proposal is evaluated.Confirms error is caused by bank master / payment method validations.
Recommended Fix Steps1. Maintain IBAN for LU bank account2. Validate LU bank key exists in BNKA3. Ensure payment method allows LU4. Validate payment method assigned in BP5. Maintain bank determination for LU banks6. Re-run proposal after fixesAfter corrections, delete proposal & restart F110.
Additional Tools to Debug- FPAYH / FPAYP (check proposal items)- BNKA (check bank key)- FIBPU (payment method usage)- F110 simulation with log level “Extended”Helps identify missing bank fields.
ConclusionPayment fails due to incomplete/incorrect LU bank data or payment method restrictions for bank country LU in FBZP. Once fully maintained, F110 will process normally.Fix master data + payment config + rerun.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: KONV-KKURS exchange rate overwrite.
entry.content:
Hello @Yesh ,

Try below options:-

 

AspectDetails / ExplanationImpact / Risk / Recommendation
FieldKONV-KKURS – Exchange rate used for converting SD condition amounts into document currencyOverwriting can corrupt audit trails, condition values, and SD/FI consistency.
SD Pricing / ReportingUsed internally by SAP pricing engine to calculate condition values (KONV-KBETR) in document currencyNon-standard rates may lead to inconsistent condition values, errors in profitability reports, and SD reporting inaccuracies (e.g., V/LA, V/I5).
FI PostingsFI document header (BKPF-KURSF) and line items rely on consistent currency conversionMismatch between SD condition values and FI postings, breaking SD-FI reconciliation.
Revenue Accounting and Reporting (RAR)RAR calculates Performance Obligation (POB) currency, Standalone Selling Price (SSP), and revenue allocations based on SD condition dataManual changes to KONV-KKURS can lead to: • Incorrect SSP calculations • Wrong revenue allocations • Inaccurate IFRS 15/ASC 606 disclosures
Data IntegrityOverwriting standard technical fields risks violating system consistencyAvoid direct modifications; maintain integrity for SD → FI → RAR flows.
SAP Standard ComplianceOverwriting KONV-KKURS is non-standard SAP behaviorCan conflict with future updates; reduces system maintainability and audit compliance.
Recommended Alternative 1Use a custom exchange rate type (OB08) and assign it to the condition typeMaintains standard behavior; ensures correct rate determination by SAP pricing engine.
Recommended Alternative 2Use Condition Base Value Formula (VOFM routine) to modify base amounts instead of changing the rateAvoids direct manipulation of KONV-KKURS; preserves SD/FI/RAR integrity.
Consultation / GovernanceAny modification affecting currency conversion should involve FI/CO and RAR teamsEnsures compliance with accounting standards (IFRS 15 / ASC 606) and avoids reporting errors.
ConclusionOverwriting KONV-KKURS directly is high-riskUse SAP-standard approaches (custom rate type or VOFM routines) to achieve the desired results safely.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: SAP & 1099 Reporting: How S/4HANA Supports US Tax Compliance
entry.content:
1. Overview of 1099 / U.S. Withholding Tax Reporting in SAP

1.1 What is 1099 Reporting?

In the U.S., businesses must issue 1099 forms to certain payees (vendors, service providers, contractors) when payments meet IRS thresholds, commonly $600 per year for non-employee compensation. The forms report payment amounts and are submitted to the IRS.

1099 covers many categories:

  • 1099-NEC: Nonemployee compensation (services, contractors)

  • 1099-MISC: Other income types (rent, royalties, prizes)

  • 1099-INT: Interest income

  • 1099-K: Payment card or third-party network transactions

  • 1099-G: Government payments, such as unemployment benefits

  • 1042-S: Payments to foreign persons or entities subject to withholding

A robust system must handle multiple vendor types, vendor master data, withholding tax codes, and aggregation logic for accurate year-end reporting.

1.2 SAP’s 1099 / Withholding Tax Functionality

In legacy SAP ERP or ECC, companies often used built-in withholding-tax and 1099 reporting functionality. With S/4HANA, SAP introduced improved compliance reporting via the Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) module. This integrates statutory and withholding tax reporting, including U.S. 1099 and 1042-S, directly in S/4HANA.

S/4HANA supports generation of print forms for 1099/1042-S reports (e.g., 1099-MISC, 1099-INT, 1099-K, 1042-S) out of the box. The “Generic Withholding Tax Report” or “Run Statutory Reports” function in DRC enables organizations to comply with IRS reporting requirements.

SAP maintains structured tables to hold 1099 statutory reporting data, ensuring vendor and payment information is stored consistently for extraction, reconciliation, and audit purposes.

2. Core Components in S/4HANA for 1099 Reporting

2.1 Vendor / Business Partner Master Data

  • Vendors or business partners must have correct tax identifiers (TIN, SSN, EIN) registered under the relevant tax category for 1099 eligibility.

  • For foreign vendors requiring 1099-NEC or 1042-S reporting, tax numbers and treaty status must be correctly maintained.

  • Vendor role assignment must be configured correctly so the DRC module knows which suppliers are 1099-eligible.

Accurate vendor master data is the foundation of successful 1099 reporting.

2.2 Withholding Tax Configuration & Codes

  • The SAP withholding tax framework must capture payments subject to withholding or 1099 reporting.

  • Withholding tax codes must be defined and assigned to the relevant 1099 or 1042-S form type, ensuring that SAP correctly identifies reportable payments.

  • Proper mapping to G/L accounts and configuration of threshold rules is essential to avoid missing or incorrect 1099 reporting.

2.3 Statutory Reporting Module (DRC)

  • S/4HANA’s DRC module provides a Fiori application for running statutory reports. It generates 1099-MISC, 1099-NEC, 1099-K, and 1042-S reports by reading data from withholding tax ledgers, vendor master records, and payment documents.

  • The module aggregates and formats output according to IRS specifications, ensuring compliance with print or electronic filing requirements.

  • SAP provides updates to reflect changes in IRS rules, such as the reintroduction of 1099-NEC in 2020.

2.4 Database Storage: Structured Tables

  • S/4HANA uses dedicated tables to store 1099 reporting data, including vendor IDs, document references, withholding tax details, and report totals.

  • HANA-native storage ensures high performance, fast data retrieval, and easier extraction for e-filing or auditing purposes.

2.5 Output / Filing

  • DRC supports generating IRS-compliant 1099 forms for print and electronic formats.

  • For advanced compliance, S/4HANA can integrate with third-party solutions for electronic filing and tax reporting automation.

  • Integration simplifies multi-state compliance and large-volume reporting.

3. Key Challenges & Known Issues in 1099 Reporting on S/4HANA

3.1 Missing or Incorrect Tax Numbers

  • Missing or incorrectly maintained TINs or SSNs in vendor master data are a leading cause of 1099 reporting failures.

  • Vendor roles and tax categories must be accurately configured to ensure correct inclusion in 1099 runs.

3.2 Withholding / Payment Configuration Issues

  • Payments may not be captured in 1099 reporting if withholding tax codes are missing or incorrectly assigned.

  • Cleared payments without proper withholding tax line items can lead to incomplete reporting.

3.3 Foreign Vendors & 1042-S Reporting

  • Payments to foreign vendors must be distinguished from domestic 1099 reporting.

  • Proper classification, treaty status, and withholding tax codes are necessary to avoid reporting errors.

3.4 IRS Rule Changes

  • Recent IRS changes, such as the separation of nonemployee compensation to 1099-NEC, require updates to SAP configuration and reporting templates.

3.5 System Limitations

  • In certain cases, foreign vendors may be incorrectly included or excluded in 1099 runs.

  • Layout issues in generated forms, such as missing recipient copies, can occur if configuration is not properly maintained.

  • Migration from legacy SAP or non-SAP systems may introduce data inconsistencies affecting 1099 reporting.

4. Implementing 1099 Reporting in S/4HANA — Step-by-Step Guide

4.1 Implementation Steps

  1. Enable Withholding Tax / 1099 Feature Scope

    • Activate statutory reporting and U.S.-specific features.

  2. Vendor Master Data Review & Cleanup

    • Verify TINs, vendor roles, and U.S. tax categories.

    • Ensure foreign vendors needing 1042-S reporting are correctly classified.

  3. Define Withholding Tax Codes

    • Create or configure codes for each 1099 or 1042-S type.

    • Map to correct G/L accounts and reporting categories.

  4. Configure Statutory Reporting

    • Set parameters for company code, reporting year, vendor selection, and tax number filters.

    • Test in a sandbox system before production.

  5. Test Data Scenarios

    • Include domestic and foreign vendors, cross-currency payments, partial payments, and credit memos.

  6. Generate Output

    • Run DRC reports to create IRS-compliant 1099/1042-S forms.

    • Validate totals, vendor information, and format compliance.

  7. Reconciliation & Audit

    • Reconcile SAP payments and 1099 totals.

    • Archive master data snapshots and final output for audit.

5. Enhancements & Integrations

5.1 Integration with External Compliance Tools

  • Integration with third-party tax engines can help automate e-filing, multi-state reporting, and complex compliance requirements.

5.2 Custom Reporting & Analytics

  • Structured data allows creation of custom reports or dashboards to monitor 1099 exposure, vendor payments, and audit readiness.

5.3 Multi-Entity / Global Compliance

  • Organizations with U.S. and non-U.S. subsidiaries can consolidate statutory reporting in a single SAP-based compliance hub.

6. Real-Life Lessons & Common Pitfalls

  1. Incorrect Vendor Master Data — Ensure TINs and vendor roles are accurate.

  2. Payments Without Correct Withholding — Enforce AP process discipline.

  3. Foreign Vendor Misclassification — Use proper 1042-S settings.

  4. IRS Form Changes — Update configuration for new forms and thresholds.

  5. High Volume Payments — Optimize HANA-native storage and extraction.

  6. Non-SAP Payments — Ensure external payments are captured for 1099 compliance.

7. Third-Party Tools: When to Consider

  • SAP S/4HANA + DRC can handle core 1099 reporting.

  • For complex or high-volume scenarios, external tools can provide e-filing, vendor outreach, and multi-state automation.

  • Hybrid approaches combine SAP data integrity with external compliance automation.

8. Known Issues & SAP Limitations

  • Incorrect inclusion of foreign vendors

  • Layout issues in generated forms

  • Migration challenges from legacy systems

  • Empty reports despite payments due to configuration changes

9. Best-Practice Recommendations

  1. Maintain clean vendor master data year-round.

  2. Standardize AP and payment processes.

  3. Run periodic mock 1099 runs.

  4. Centralize compliance governance.

  5. Leverage third-party compliance tools where necessary.

  6. Archive all data and reports for audit purposes.

  7. Stay current with IRS and SAP updates.

10. Future Outlook

  • Deeper integration with external tax engines

  • Improved foreign vendor and 1042-S support

  • Enhanced analytics and dashboards

  • Automated compliance workflows

  • Global compliance consolidation

Conclusion

SAP S/4HANA with Document & Reporting Compliance provides a unified, auditable, and scalable approach for 1099 reporting. Success depends on accurate vendor data, proper configuration, disciplined AP processes, and governance. Proper implementation allows SAP to become the backbone of your U.S. statutory compliance, ensuring accurate and timely reporting for all 1099 and 1042-S obligations.

entry.title: Re: About metric "Updates in Error Status (older 1 day)"...
entry.content:
The metric "Updates in Error Status (older 1 day)" data is collected from the Update header table VBHDR every 5 minutes. 
If the "Update date/time" is older than 1 day that the data collection timestamp, it will be collected.
It it possible to check the data in SM13. Please refer to the KB 0003692805 How the metric "Updates in Error Status (older 1 day)" metric collects data to SAP Cloud ALM Health Monitoring for more details

entry.title: How to Combine Multiple MRP Purchase Proposals and Apply Minimum Lot Size in S/4HANA Public Cloud?
entry.content:
Hi everyone

I am using SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, and I encountered an issue related to MRP purchase proposal consolidation and minimum lot size.

After running MRP, I receive multiple purchase demand elements, for example:

  • Requirement A = 20 pcs

  • Requirement B = 30 pcs

I want to combine A + B and create one purchase order.
I also want to apply a minimum lot size, for example 50 pcs.

A + B = 50 pcs → meets the minimum lot size
If the total does not reach 50, MRP should add remaining quantity.

Example:
A (20) + B (20) = 40 → System should propose 50.

Actual behavior in Public Cloud

Currently, the minimum lot size is applied per requirement, so the system creates:

  • Requirement A → 50 pcs

  • Requirement B → 50 pcs

Total = 100 pcs, which is not what we want.

Questions

  1. Is it possible in S/4HANA Public Cloud to apply minimum lot size based on the total combined quantity, not per requirement?
    → For example: A + B + additional quantity to meet the minimum lot size.

  2. In the generated Purchase Order, I cannot see the reference to the original MRP elements (e.g., MRP element number / MRP demand reference such as sales order numbers).
    Is there any configuration that allows the PO to display which MRP elements (A and B) it was created from?
    Or is this not supported in Public Cloud?

Any guidance or confirmation would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you!

entry.title: Re: Remove lines in fields
entry.content:
Hello,

Yes, you can either hide those lines or display "N/A" conditionally, using a formula.

If that's a line you've drawn in Crystal reports, you can: right click on it and click 'Format Line', look for the X2 button next to a Suppress checkbox. In here you can write a formula to check the value of the WC field. e.g., something to the effect of:

{field}* = "QC Plan" Or {field} = "OKU"

This will hide the line when those values appear in the WC field. 

Alternatively, you can create a formula that displays "N/A" based off the value of the WC field. To do that you can go to the field explorer, right click on Formula fields, click new, give it a name, and enter your formula. You'd want something like:

If Not IsNull({wcfield}*) And ({wcfield} = "QC Plan" Or {wcfield} = "OKU") Then

 "N/A";

You can then drag and drop the formula into your report.

*just a placeholder to demonstrate, you'll need to select the field from the Report Fields dropdown at the top of the formula editor.

entry.title: Auto-Clearing of Billing Invoices Against Credit Memos in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Dear SAP Support Team,

Is there auto-clearing functionality in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, where billing invoices are automatically cleared against billing credit memos when both documents contain the same values? The expectation is that the clearing should take place immediately after the credit memo is posted.

In the ECC environment, this requirement was handled using Transaction Code F.13 (Automatic Clearing). We would like to confirm whether a similar functionality is available or can be configured in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Requesting your guidance on the following points:

  1. Is automatic clearing between billing invoices and billing credit memos supported in SAP Public Cloud?
  2. If yes, what configuration and automation options are recommended to achieve this?
  3. If not available by default, please suggest any alternative processes or automation options within SAP Public Cloud.

Kindly review and confirm the feasibility of this requirement.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Auto-Clearing of Billing Invoices Against Credit Memo...
entry.content:
As mentioned in this Help Portal, Automatic Clearing functionality is available in the following apps:

  • Clear Open Items Automatically app
  • Use the app Schedule General Ledger Jobs app with the job template Automatic Clearing

The automatic clearing program works based on the user criteria defined in SSCUI 101971 (Manage Your Solution - Configure Your Solution - Finance - General Settings - Prepare Automatic Clearing) and also according to fixed system criteria. Special case is the GR/IR account clearing.

Please review this SAP KBA for your reference:

  • 3147360 - Automatic and GR/IR Clearing Process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

entry.title: Re: How to Filter Current vs. Previous Year Data Using a...
entry.content:
@AhmadAzaanFarooqui 

One option is that you can create restricted measure based on dynamic time offset to previous year for the second table. The other option is that you can use scripting to read the Input control selection , offset it by a year and then pass it as a dimension filter to the second table.

 

Nikhil

entry.title: How to implement AI-assisted Scenarios in Cloud ERP Private and how to solve common problems
entry.content:
Preamble

Before we start delving into this topic, I would first like to define the scope of what we are talking about when we say AI-assisted use case (you may also find sometimes the terms 'Embedded AI', or 'SAP Managed AI' being used to describe the same things). Well, put simply, these are AI use cases or scenarios that run through an SAP Managed BTP as a conduit to an AI generative service, that is provisioned, and fully managed by SAP. This in contrast to an AI service that runs through your very own SAP AI core setup in your own BTP. At the time of writing this post, the SAP managed AI services that are candidates for this post are the ones depicted by the image below and accessible by this link to the SAP Discovery Centre (they are found by filtering on the product = SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private and Commercial Type = Premium). By the filter and title of this blog you will have understood that this applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. These capabilities are not available in SAP S/4HANA On-premise deployments. In addition, typically these AI uses cases require for a commercial construct to be in place, i.e you have purchased AI Units.

The process

The process required to activate an AI-assisted use case, at a high level, has to follow the steps below. We will go into the details of each step:

  1. Identify the AI use case(s) that are relevant and applicable to your organization
  2. Gather the information that is required throughout the activation process
  3. Request your SAP Managed -BTP- AI instance
  4. Perform the AI use case setup prerequisites
  5. Perform the ISLM connection setup
  6. Perform the AI use case activation
  7. Perform application specific configurations
  8. Test and use the AI scenario

1 Identify relevant and applicable use cases

If you are not sure where to start in your AI Journey, then I would recommend you first start by executing an AI Discovery Workshop to understand what AI is, what it can do for your organization, identify the high value use cases or headaches you want to solve with AI, build a roadmap and then leverage the available SAP delivered AI-assisted use cases (whether base or premium).

If you want to just get going and trying anything to see what sticks, then I would in any case recommend that you make your first point of call the SAP Business AI Discovery Centre AI Catalog, which lists the entirety of SAP's AI offering. Having applied the required filters, you will then be able to view the offering that applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, and SAP Managed AI scenarios. For each of the available scenarios, you will find a lot of very valuable information that will help you to understand what the use case is, its benefits, where to start, a business value 3 pager and more. Taking the AI-Assisted Journal Upload scenario as an example of the documentation available for a given scenario is shown below:

 One you have taken stock of this page you should be in a position to know if the scenario is relevant and applies to your organization, i.e:

  • Am I using the underlying functional area that is required to benefit from this use case? (There is no point trying to activate the AI-Assisted Conversational Planning scenario if you do not use Advanced Transportation Management!)
  • Am I technically on the right platform to activate a given scenario? (Note that not all scenarios are available for all versions of SAP S/4HANA, or indeed for all FPS's of a given version. The general rule being that the more recent (latest and greatest) your platform is, the broader the offering you can access.
  • Are there any other prerequisites? This could vary, i.e:
    • Some scenarios are 'Hybrid' scenarios and require for Joule to be already fully activated,
    • Some scenarios require for Fiori to be available (either SAP Fiori Launchpad or Workzone) - no scenario runs in the SAP GUI!

2 Gather the information required

If you are moving on to this section, then I assume that you have identified the scenario(s) you want to implement and deemed them as being relevant and applicable!

For each AI use case, you will need certain pieces of information that will be called for at different points of the setup. I recommend that before you proceed on to step 3, you have those pieces of information fully identified and available - this will confirm that you have read the SAP help and not guess your way through the activation!

2.1 The technical name of the AI Scenario

Each scenario (eg: AI-assisted Journal Upload) will have a specific technical name, which is the ISLM (Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management) name of the scenario. You will need this technical name when you request the SAP Managed BTP instance and when you configure a scenario in your system. Taking the AI-assisted Journal Upload scenario as an example, we can find this name in the SAP help in the Prerequisites / setting up the system section, as shown below, and we can see is FIN_INTLGNT_JRNLUPLD :

2.2 The OAuth 2.0 Client Profile

The next piece of information you'll need to collect is the OAuth 2.0 client profile. You will need this when you configure the ISLM scenario in your system. Again staying on the example of the  AI-assisted Journal Upload scenario, we can find this information in the SAP help in the Prerequisites / Setting up the Connection to Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management, as shown below and we can see is S4_PR_IJU_FIN :

 Note, that not all scenarios will list a OAuth 2.0 Client Profile Name - but you do need this information! In this case, I would suggest you follow the guidance provided in this SAP help page and use one of the profiles mentioned in the section Procedure.

3 Request your SAP Managed BTP -AI- instance

As previously mentioned, these AI use cases will run through an SAP Managed Instance. You must request it using the familiar SAP support process, creating an incident on a specific component. The process that you must follow to request this SAP Managed BTP Instance is detailed in the SAP help page Requesting Access to SAP AI Services on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).

Note that you will need to follow this requesting process for every combination of AI Scenario and System ID and Client - do not attempt to re-use previously provided assets. When you create the incident, make sure that you user ID also has the appropriate authorizations to create Private Cloud Service Requests (See SAP Support note 2669783 for more information)

The SAP Support team that will receive your ticket are well versed in handling these requests, and I suggest you follow the below template to expedite your request.

  • Message Title: Requesting SAP Managed BTP - AI Instance
  • Component to use : CA-S4H-BTPAI
  • Priority : As required
  • Message Body: As per SAP standard process, herewith this message requesting provisioning of an SAP Managed BTP - AI Instance with the following details:
    • S/4 System ID and client where the ISLM will be configured : ABC / 123 (Your own system ID and client)​
    • Name of the intelligent scenario: FIN_INTLGNT_JRNUPLD (Journal Upload) (The code/name of the Scenario for which you are requesting an SAP Managed BTP)​
    • Preferred Authentication Method : OAuth 2.0 with client credential flow  (preferred) OR OAuth 2.0 with mTLS *​
    • Preferred Data Center : EU10​

* Choose one - if mTLS, then provide a certificate as attachment to your upload.

Text in Orange Colour denotes text that you must amend /personalize as required.

Once SAP Support receives your request, the team will verify that the request can be fulfilled (You have AI units and the system is a RISE system). If yes, once provisioned, they will create a service request for you, that you must submit in order to be able to download from it several digital assets, namely a JSON service Key and one or more SSL Certificates. Download these and store them in a safe and secure place. You will need them in order to securely setup the connection from your SAP S/4HANA System to the SAP Managed BTP instance.

4 Perform the AI use case setup prerequisites

Once your reach this point you will start to configure your system per se and carry out the following prerequisite activities.

4.1 Setting up the ISLM Background Jobs

Several background jobs are required to be setup, so that the ISLM scenario is able to stay updated and pull the required content from the SAP managed BTP. In order to setup the required background jobs, follow the instructions in the SAP Help, indicated in this SAP help page. This is a one time activity - it does not need to be done each and every time you activate a new scenario - only the first time.

4.2 Setting up the Trust to the SAP Managed BTP instance

As previously indicated, SAP support will have provided you with 1 to 4 SSL certificates. You must import these SSL certificates into your system, using the transaction STRUST. Further information regarding where and how these certificates must be imported is detailed in this SAP help page. SAP support will also provide you with a more detailed guide in the service request, when they hand over to you the SSL certificates in case you are new to this and require a bit more guidance to do this.

5 Perform the ISLM connection setup

In this step you will maintain the connection to the SAP Managed instance and it is here that the pieces of information you collected at the beginning (the technical name of the AI (ISLM) scenario, the name of the OAuth 2.0 Client Profile and very importantly the JSON service key that SAP support provided you. The procedure required to perform this step is described in the SAP help here, Maintain Connection for an Intelligent Scenario.

However this step is sufficiently important, that I will add some guiding screenshots below. To help you follow along, we will go through the activation of a Hybrid AI-assisted use case, in the area of Sales and Distribution. The specifics of this feature is document here, and we will be activating the AI-assisted Sales Order Fulfillment scenario.  Make sure to always read the SAP help before you start configuring a scenario. Because the system I use is based on SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud release 2025, there is a subtlety I must be aware of - the scenario and model setup names are different to lower releases!

To recap before I get started the information I will need is:

  • The technical name of the scenario : SD_INT_AI (and I will be interested to select the SD_INT_AI_GPT4O model)
  • The name of the OAuth 2.0 Client Profile: I could not find it in the help page, thus I will select ISLM_SAPGENAI_OAUTH_PRF_HCP (for Generative AI) that was documented here,  if one is not auto proposed when I do the configuration
  • I have the JSON service key ready that was given to me by SAP Support.

You can access the ISLM connection mapping via the transaction code ISLM_CONN_MAP. Start by creating a new connection.

Use the search help to select the scenario for which you want to create a connection.

 In the next popup, you will need to (1) enter the OAuth 2.0 Client Profile. If it is filled for you, keep the proposed value. Paste the content of the JSON service key  SAP Support provided to you, as shown in (2), and then click Next.

 The connection details will be validated, and you can see that SAP will create certain artifacts for you, namely (1) an RFC destination, and (2) an OAuth 2.0 Client configuration.

You are also (3) invited to check the connection so go ahead and do that by clicking (4) - Connection Check.

 What you are looking for is (1) a 'Green' Connection status indicator. You can then (2) save the profile. If you get an error message, then please check the section later 'Troubleshooting common problems'.

 Once you return to the main connection screen, you will see your scenario (1) appear in the list. You can also at anytime here perform a connection check (2).

Now that the scenario is saved, your SAP system will start to sync the AI content to your system. Give it 5-10 minutes before moving on to the next step!

6 Perform the AI use case activation

Again referring to the SAP help, the activation process is described here in the page Activate and Deactivate. I will again here provide some screenshots. For this step you need to navigate to your Fiori Launchpad and open the app named 'Intelligent Scenario Management' app.

You can (1) use the available filters to narrow down the list of scenarios and locate (2) the one that you are interested in. Again the devil is in the detail. Note that there are other scenarios named SD_INT_AI*, so I have to make sure to pick the right one ! As per the SAP help, and the scenario for which I created the connection, I select SD_INT_AI. I click on the line to go into the details.

As per the documentation for the scenario, 3 models are available for me to choose from. I will select SD_INT_AI_GPT4O, and then click on the line to progress in its configuration.

 A new pane will open to the right, showing me 'trainings'. I select (1) the training and then click (2) to 'Deploy' the model. Note that at this time the number of deployments is 0 (3) - meaning none exist yet.

 A popup will appear showing you the (1) model name and version, then click (2) to deploy the model. Note in some cases the model version field could be blank. In those cases I would suggest you enter 'latest'.

 The deployment will then progress.

 And hopefully finish with the status (1) 'Deployed' if all goes well. You then need to (2) select the deployment and activate it (3).

 Once the activation is complete, you will see this information indicated, as shown below.

The scenario is now 'live'.

7 Perform application specific configurations

This section will vary for each scenario that you are trying to activate - there is no set rule. Whilst usually there will at minimum be a need to fine tune or create roles and / or authorizations, some scenarios will require you to perform application specific configurations. For example the AI-assisted conversational planning scenario requires that you perform some configurations in the area of your transportation planning layouts, so make sure to read the SAP help or consult the prerequisite SAP support notes that provide you this detail.

8 Test and use the AI scenario

Once your setup and configuration is complete, you can proceed with testing your scenario. In this case we activated a Hybrid (Joule) use case, so let's try a prompt associated with this capability! Success !

We have now activated an Ai-assisted (Embedded AI) Scenario!

 

Troubleshooting common problems

I am also below documenting some of the more common issues that I have seen implementations come across.

HTTP failure in connection mapping.

When you create a connection mapping, and upon checking the connection, you do not get a 'Green' light, but instead an error message saying 'HTTP failure, processing failed, invalid state, invalid timeout or others', and if your system is hosted on a hyperscaler, then you need to perform some additional configuration.

 

So go ahead, save your connection mapping (with an error state), then head on to the SAP help and check this troubleshooting section. Essentially, you will need to maintain a proxy and a port in the RFC destination and OAuth 2.0 client configuration that were auto generated when you created the connection mapping. So go ahead and maintain the values 'proxy' and port '3128' as shown below.

In the 'Technical Settings' tab of the RFC destination:

And in the Access settings of the OAuth 2.0 client configuration:

If you are unsure about the names of the RFC destination or OAuth 2.0 client configuration, you will find those in the connection mapping settings, for your AI scenario.

 

Scenario is not registered or published

If you try to create a connection mapping for a  scenario, and you get an error message such as 'The scenario <NAME_OF_THE _SCENARIO> is not registered or published', and if you are on SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01, then please raise a Service Request with your nominated ECS contact and ask them to verify SAP support note https://me.sap.com/notes/3437407 - they will know what to do.

 
Cannot Deploy and activate a scenario

You have done some configuration that you believe complete, but when you come to deploying and activating the scenario, you find that you are not able to do so, and in addition, you see a message box like below in the 'Intelligent Scenario Management' app.

Assuming you have been able to create the connection mapping without any errors, the likely culprit is that you have not set up the ISLM background jobs. Check that all required ISLM jobs as described above have been setup.

entry.title: How to extract the termination initiation date of contingent workers in SuccessFactors
entry.content:
For contingent workers, we have not setup any workflows for their terminations. Their termination is captured only through the contract end date, so there is no termination initiation date or similar field to compare against.

Because of this, we are unable to determine whether a contingent worker termination was backdated (in case of termination performed before the recorded contract end date.)

Ex: If a contingent worker is maintained with End of Contingent as Dec 10th, but if there is a early termination and if they terminate him effective Nov 10th, but updated this in the system on Nov 25th, this is a case of backdated termination in Contingent workers. 

In this case we are required to extract the data of action in the system as Nov 25th and as the workflow is not available in this case, we are not able to report on the workflow initiation date as well.

We have also tried to use the last modified date of job information, but as that is being overridden for any changes being done on the contingent worker record post the Nov 25th, we are not able to use the last modified date as well.

Requesting guidance on how we can report or identify backdated terminations for contingent workers based on the above scenario with the fields currently available in Report Centre.

entry.title: Re: #CoE#GDTD设置审批流选择不到对应用户
entry.content: Hello，您在管理采购订单工作流中新建工作流时，收件人选择仅显示3个用户，而实际业务用户有上百人，这通常是由 于SAP 公有云的严格权限与职责分离（Segregation of Duties, SoD）机制以及 工作流上下文相关的动态用户过滤逻辑 所导致。 在 SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 中： 用户是否出现在工作流的“收件人”列表中，不取决于“系统中有多少用户”，而是取决于： 1.该用户是否分配了与当前业务对象（如采购订单）相关的 Business Role（业务角色）； 2.该角色是否具有处理此工作流任务的权限（例如：审批采购订单）； 3.是否满足工作流模板中定义的候选人规则（如基于组织架构、采购组、公司代码等） 请优先检查： 1.用户是否启用为 Workflow Recipient； 2.是否分配了正确的 Business Role； 3.采购订单字段（如采购组）是否匹配审批人范围

entry.title: Simplifying Global Compliance – How SAP S/4HANA Transforms Compliance Document Management
entry.content:
In today’s global business landscape, companies face increasing pressure to maintain compliance with ever-changing regulations. Managing critical documentation such as Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) or product labels manually can be time-consuming and error-prone, slowing down operations and creating risk.

With SAP S/4HANA for Product Compliance, organizations can simplify and automate compliance documentation across all markets. The Compliance Document Management capability centralizes all regulatory documents, ensuring they are accurate, up to date, and distributed automatically to the right recipients.

What makes this approach so powerful is that it’s fully integrated into core business processes. From product creation to final delivery, the system checks for required documentation, issues automatic notifications if something is missing, and ensures that all shipments comply with global regulations. Updates to documents are handled automatically, so customers always receive the latest, legally valid versions without additional effort.

What the Video Covers:

  • How SAP S/4HANA automates compliance document creation, monitoring, and distribution
  • How integrated checks prevent non-compliant deliveries
  • How analytics ensure transparency and proactive compliance management
  • And how automation helps reduce risk and accelerate global product launches

This topic is especially close to my heart because I believe that compliance, when automated and embedded, is not a burden but a business advantage. It ensures safety, builds trust, and enables companies to operate globally, with confidence and efficiency.

SAP Video - In brief: SAP Product Compliance - Compliance Document Management

Watch the video and let’s discuss how SAP S/4HANA for Product Compliance can help your organization transform documentation management into a strategic strength.

entry.title: Re: Custom Adobe Form How to Print 7 Outputs with Differe...
entry.content:
Hello Chris,

Thank you for your detailed explanation , it was very helpful.

I followed the approach you suggested and implemented a repeated subform in the Adobe Form. I set the minCount = 7 and maxCount = 7, and now the PDF correctly generates 7 copies of the invoice.

However, I am facing two issues:

1. How to identify the copy number inside the form logic?

Since S/4HANA Public Cloud outputs only one form, the backend does not send any “Copy Number” or a field to differentiate the 7 iterations.
Because of this, I am not sure where to write the script logic such as:

  • Copy 1 → Original for Recipient

  • Copy 2 → Duplicate for Transporter

  • Copy 3 → Triplicate for Supplier

  • Copy 4 → Extra Copy 1

  • Copy 5 → Extra Copy 2

  • Copy 6 → Extra Copy 3

  • Copy 7 → Extra Copy 4

I need a way to detect the index of the repeated subform so I can assign the right label in JavaScript.
Could you please guide where to access the instance index inside the repeated subform?

2. Line items are not repeating for each copy

The header section is repeating 7 times correctly, but the item table is printed only once.
It seems the item subform is not included inside the repeated parent subform.

Do we need to place the entire invoice layout (header + items + totals) inside the repeatable subform to ensure that each copy contains all line items?
Or is there any best practice for repeating nested subforms without breaking pagination?

Summary of my current implementation

  • Repeated subform (min/max = 7) → OK

  • 7 invoice copies visible → OK

  • Line items not repeating → Issue

  • No index or copy number from backend → Issue

Any guidance on these two missing parts would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you again for your support!

entry.title: Extend Transport-related Check-Framework in Generic application
entry.content:
Transport Checks in Generic application - Enhancements in SP16

Introduction

With the SP16 release, we have enhanced the transport-related checks available in the Generic Application (UI5). Until SP11, only ATC checks were supported, and users relied heavily on the CRM Web UI for all other validations. In this blog post, I will walk you through what has changed in SP16, which checks are now available directly in the Generic UI application

Enhancements from SP11 to SP16

Previously, the Generic application supported only ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC) checks, meaning users had to switch to the CRM Web UI for other essential validations. As of SP16, SAP has enabled the full set of transport-related checks directly within the Generic application. This includes:

  • Down-Grade Protection (DGP) Checks

  • Critical Object Checks

  • Cross Reference Checks (CRC)

  • ABAP Test Cockpit (ATC)

  • Code Inspector Checks (CIC)

These checks are now accessible in My Work Items, My Change Documents, and My Defect Corrections.

You can refer to SAP’s documentation for deeper technical details: Performing Transport-Related Checks | SAP Help Portal 

 

 

Check Details and Navigation

To review detailed information for each check or perform additional actions, users can still navigate to the CRM Web UI, which continues to provide the most comprehensive view of transport results.

However, it’s important to note that:

  • DGP and CRC checks are not available in My Defect Corrections, because Focused Build Defect Corrections do not use an Urgent Change workflow or Preliminary Import workflow.

  • Even so, as of SP16, the Transport-Related Checks tab is now available in My Defect Corrections for ATC, Critical Object, and Code Inspector checks.

To get more details about each of the checks and to perform actions on the check, you need to navigate to the CRM Web UI. 

DGP and CRC is not available in My Defect Corrections as for Focus Build Defect corrections we do not have an Urgent Change workflow nor any Preliminary Import Workflow in place. In case My Defect Corrections, with SP16 we have enabled the Transport-Related Checks tab itself to perform the various checks for ATC, Critical Object Checks and Code Inspector Checks. 

Performing Transport-Related Checks in the Generic Application

A major usability improvement in SP16 is the ability to run transport-related checks directly from the Generic application.

The "Perform Check" button in the Transport-Related Checks tab now triggers a background job—similar to the CRM Web UI—to execute all relevant checks for the associated Work Item, Defect Correction, or Change Document.

This enhancement removes the need to switch to CRM Web UI and allows users to work more efficiently within a single interface.

Conclusion

With SP16, we have taken a significant step toward improving the user experience by making all major transport-related checks available directly in the Generic application. 

If you have questions about these new capabilities or want to share your experiences with SP16, feel free to leave a comment—I’d be happy to discuss further!

entry.title: What’s New in SAP Cloud ALM: Test Management Updates for 2025
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP is broadening SAP Cloud ALM by new capabilities which leads to efficiency, transparency, automation, and quality of the implementation projects. The newest Test Management capabilities presented at the SAP ALM Summit EMEA 2025 clearly indicate that SAP is very committed to providing a modern, cloud-driven ALM experience.

Following the latest SAP ALM Summit announcements, SAP has made a huge number of improvements in Test Management since late 2024.

The major upgrades that have been introduced cover following topics:

Improved structuring & scalability:

  • Mass Upload of Manual Test Cases – making it easy to bulk onboard testing assets
  • Direct Upload of SAP Best Practices Test Cases
  • Test Case Assignment to Process Hierarchy
  • References for Test Cases (e.g., data sheets, sample files)
  • Test Cases Assignment to Applications & Interfaces

 

Enhanced orchestration & sequencing:

  • Simple Test Sequences for defining execution order
  • Change Test Case Assignment to scope, solution processes, and diagrams

 

Better governance & data quality:

  • Restricting deletion: Helping the user to not delete test cases with existing results
  • Reset Test Action for a clean re-execution
  • Test Plan Copy for reusability
  • Test Plan Status filter for more focused execution views
  • Defect Reporting per Test Plan
  • Create or assign Features directly from Defects

These enhancements substantially help to cut down on the manual work, increase the consistency level, and give test managers greater authority over test lifecycle governance.

 

Overview of the most significant Test Management Improvements

The sections below highlight the most significant Test Management enhancements in SAP Cloud ALM, along with illustrative screenshots

Test Case Assignment to Process Hierarchy

This feature enhances the connection between business design and test execution. Testers can get the preparation and execution status directly in the process context

 

Defect Reporting per Test Plan

A dedicated view enables the team to analyze defect trends, locate blockers, and speed up the resolution process.

 

Mass upload of manual Test Cases

While​‍​‌‍​‍‌​‍​‌‍​‍‌ companies are moving their operations to the cloud at a fast pace, testing teams are usually put in a difficult position of figuring out how they can get a huge number of test cases onboard in a quick, consistent manner and without having to do manual data entry. The recently launched mass upload feature is the answer to this problem in the first place, and it also paves the way for a next-generation scalable method of creating and managing tests in SAP Cloud ​‍​‌‍​‍‌​‍​‌‍​‍‌ALM.

 

 

Test Sequences:

Traditional test execution often relies on manual coordination. Testers must communicate informally about which test case should be executed when, and dependencies must be tracked separately. The new Test Sequences capability in SAP Cloud ALM addresses this need directly, enabling more structure and clarity in complex test cycles.

 

Change Test Case assignment to scope, solution process and diagram:

This​‍​‌‍​‍‌​‍​‌‍​‍‌ improvement makes sure that test cases are updated according to the solution design as it changes, thus, testers and architects do not have to duplicate the content.

 

Conclusion:

These​‍​‌‍​‍‌​‍​‌‍​‍‌ changes drastically cut down on the manual work required, make collaboration easier between project teams, and extend control to the entire testing lifecycle across the organization.

SAP Cloud ALM is thus the tool to help customers who are still on their way to the cloud but want to keep up with the pace and deliver consistent, high-quality results.

For ALM practitioners, test managers, and project teams, now is the ideal time to explore these new features and embed them into your daily practices.

entry.title: Leveraging SAP AI Core & AI Launchpad: A Code-Driven Comparison of LangChain and LangGraph
entry.content:
As AI development evolves, we see multiple frameworks emerge - LangChain, LangGraph, Agent Frameworks, RAG frameworks, and more. With so many choices, one common question developers face is:  “Which framework should I use for my project?”

The short answer: both LangChain and LangGraph are useful,  but for different types of workflows.

Think of them as part of the same family:

  • LangChain -> the foundation

  • LangGraph -> the orchestration layer built on top of LangChain

LangChain - The building block

As the name suggests, LangChain works like a chain: it follows a sequential, linear flow of tasks. Along with chaining steps, you can also integrate tools and other components during execution, making it flexible for straightforward LLM workflows.

What can you do - 

  • Integrate Models (LLMs, embeddings)
  • Integrate Tools (search, calculators, APIs)
  • Have a Memory (conversation history)
  • Chains (a sequence of prompts or tasks)

For example :

You can use it for simple workflows as below to summarize the tickets

Using LangChain would make sense here since -

  • There are no decisions
  • No human approval step is need
  • No branching or looping is required
  • The pipeline is fixed
  • The steps are linear

Now lets experiment this with code: 

Prerequisites
  • Access to SAP AI Core.
  • A registered LLM deployment available in your AI Core tenant.
  • Download, install Vs code and python
  • Setup a virtual environment 
  • Install sap-ai-sdk-gen, langchain and langgraph within this venv to isolate the dependencies
  • Please have your AI Core configured file Initial Setup 

    With your service key follow the configuration section in this Documentation to set the following environment variables:

    • AICORE_CLIENT_ID: This represents the client ID.
    • AICORE_CLIENT_SECRET: This stands for the client secret.
    • AICORE_AUTH_URL: This is the URL used to retrieve a token using the client ID and secret.
    • AICORE_BASE_URL: This is the URL of the service (with suffix /v2).
    • AICORE_RESOURCE_GROUP: This represents the resource group that should be used. (The standard resource group is "default")

Step 1) Import Required Packages

from gen_ai_hub.proxy.langchain.openai import ChatOpenAI
from gen_ai_hub.proxy.core.proxy_clients import get_proxy_client
from langchain_core.prompts import PromptTemplate

Step 2) Initialize the Model through SAP GenAI Hub 

proxy_client ensures authentication and routing of calls.

model = ChatOpenAI(proxy_model_name="gpt-5", proxy_client=get_proxy_client())

Step 3) Create a Prompt to Classify the Issue

  • ticket_prompt defines a template with a variable placeholder {ticket}.

  • The model will read the ticket text and respond with one category.

 

ticket_prompt = PromptTemplate(
    input_variables=["ticket"],
    template="Classify this SAP support ticket into one category: "
             "Performance, Integration, Authorization, UI, ABAP Error.\n\nTicket: {ticket}"
)

Step 4) Create a Second Prompt for Severity Decision

  • This uses the model's previous output (classification) as input.

  • Purpose: Determine if escalation is required.

  • Expected outputs: "Yes" or "No".

severity_prompt = PromptTemplate(
    input_variables=["classification"],
    template="Based on the classification '{classification}', decide if escalation is needed.Respond wit Yes or No"
)

Step 5) Create Chains Using LCEL (LangChain Expression Language)

  • | (pipe operator) connects prompt -> model like a flow.

  • Meaning - When this chain runs, take prompt -> insert input -> call model -> give output.
classification_chain = ticket_prompt | model
severity_chain = severity_prompt | model

Step 6) Run Classification

ticket = "The user is facing issues while logging in SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud with thier I-User ID"
classification_result = classification_chain.invoke({"ticket": ticket})
classification = classification_result.content

print(f"Classification: {classification}")

And your output would look something like this - 

But What if the workflow isn't linear??

Let’s extend the same scenario:

Once a support ticket arrives, the system first extracts and classifies the issue type (e.g., Authorization, Performance, UI, Integration, ABAP Error). After classification, the model’s confidence score is evaluated.

  • If the LLM is confident enough, the system proceeds directly to the escalation decision.

  • If confidence is low, the workflow pauses and sends the ticket to a human agent for review.
    The agent may either approve the model’s decision or correct it and if corrected, the classification step is repeated.

Once a final classification is confirmed, the system evaluates the severity level:

  • If severity is high, the ticket is escalated and a notification email is automatically triggered.

  • If the severity is low or moderate, the workflow ends without escalation.

Now the workflow includes:

- loops
- human-in-loop
- branching logic
- retry mechanisms

This is where LangChain becomes restrictive and LangGraph comes into picture -

LangGraph is built on top of LangChain, but instead of linear chains, it uses a graph-style architecture. Instead of a straight pipeline, you get a flexible architecture where your AI application can branch, loop, make decisions, or even include human approvals 

It turns your workflow from:

Step1 -> Step2 -> Step3

into more of a graph:

Lets look at the code now

from typing import TypedDict, Optional
from langgraph.graph import StateGraph, END
from gen_ai_hub.proxy.core.proxy_clients import get_proxy_client
from gen_ai_hub.proxy.langchain.openai import ChatOpenAI
from langchain_core.prompts import PromptTemplate



# --------------------------------------------------
# 1) Connect to SAP AI Core Model via SAP GenAI Hub
# --------------------------------------------------
# This model will be used in all decision steps (classification, confidence check, escalation decision)

model = ChatOpenAI(
    proxy_model_name="gpt-5",
    proxy_client=get_proxy_client()
)


# --------------------------------------------------
# 2) Define Prompts for Each AI Task
# --------------------------------------------------

# Prompt for classifying the incoming support ticket into a predefined category.
classification_prompt = PromptTemplate(
    input_variables=["ticket"],
    template="""
You are an SAP support assistant.

Classify the following SAP support ticket into ONE category only:
Performance, Integration, Authorization, UI, ABAP Error.

Ticket: {ticket}
"""
)

# Prompt to check how confident the model is in its classification.
confidence_prompt = PromptTemplate(
    input_variables=["classification"],
    template="""
Evaluate your confidence in the following classification:
"{classification}"

Respond only with: High or Low
"""
)

# Prompt to decide whether escalation is needed based on classification.
severity_prompt = PromptTemplate(
    input_variables=["classification"],
    template="""
Based on the issue classification "{classification}", decide if this should be escalated to Level 2 SAP Support.

Respond exactly with Yes or No.
"""
)


# Connect prompts to the SAP AI model.
classification_chain = classification_prompt | model
confidence_chain = confidence_prompt | model
severity_chain = severity_prompt | model



# --------------------------------------------------
# 3) Define the State Shape for the Workflow
# --------------------------------------------------
# This holds all data as the workflow progresses.

class TicketState(TypedDict, total=False):
    ticket: str
    classification: Optional[str]
    confidence: Optional[str]          # "high" / "low"
    severity: Optional[str]            # "high" / "low/moderate"
    retry_count: int                   # Counts human corrections
    escalated: bool
    email_sent: bool



# --------------------------------------------------
# 4) Workflow Node Functions
# --------------------------------------------------
# Each function represents a step in the process.


# Step 1: Classify the ticket using the LLM.
def classify(state: TicketState) -> TicketState:
    response = classification_chain.invoke({"ticket": state["ticket"]})
    state["classification"] = response.content.strip()
    print(f"Classification → {state['classification']}")
    return state


# Step 2: Check how confident the model is.
def check_confidence(state: TicketState) -> TicketState:
    
    # If a human already corrected the classification,
    # we trust the human and override confidence to HIGH.
    if state.get("retry_count", 0) > 0:
        state["confidence"] = "high"
        print("Confidence overridden → high (human validated)")
        return state

    # Otherwise, let the AI evaluate confidence.
    response = confidence_chain.invoke({"classification": state["classification"]})
    state["confidence"] = response.content.strip().lower()
    print(f"Model Confidence → {state['confidence']}")
    return state



# Step 3: Human-in-the-loop step if confidence was low.
def human_review(state: TicketState) -> TicketState:
    print("HUMAN-IN-THE-LOOP REQUIRED:")
    print(f"Suggested classification: {state['classification']}")

    # Human may approve or correct the classification.
    updated = input("Enter correct classification (or press enter to approve): ").strip()

    if updated:
        print(f"Human corrected classification → {updated}")
        state["classification"] = updated

    # Increase retry count so system knows review already happened.
    state["retry_count"] = state.get("retry_count", 0) + 1
    return state



# Step 4: Decide whether the issue needs escalation.
def decide_escalation(state: TicketState) -> TicketState:
    response = severity_chain.invoke({"classification": state["classification"]})
    decision = response.content.strip().lower()

    # Convert response into workflow logic format.
    state["severity"] = "high" if decision == "yes" else "low/moderate"
    print(f"Escalation Decision → Severity: {state['severity']}")
    return state



# Step 5: If severity is high, escalate the ticket.
def escalate(state: TicketState) -> TicketState:
    print("Escalating ticket to Level 2 support...")
    state["escalated"] = True
    return state



# Step 6: After escalation, send an email notification.
def send_mail(state: TicketState) -> TicketState:
    print("Sending escalation email...")
    state["email_sent"] = True
    return state



# Step 7: End the workflow.
def end(state: TicketState) -> TicketState:
    print("Workflow Complete.")
    return state



# --------------------------------------------------
# 5) Build LangGraph Workflow
# --------------------------------------------------

graph = StateGraph(TicketState)

graph.add_node("classify", classify)
graph.add_node("confidence", check_confidence)
graph.add_node("human_review", human_review)
graph.add_node("decide_escalation", decide_escalation)
graph.add_node("escalate", escalate)
graph.add_node("send_mail", send_mail)
graph.add_node("end", end)

# The workflow always begins with classification.
graph.set_entry_point("classify")

# After classifying, always check confidence.
graph.add_edge("classify", "confidence")


# Route: Confidence determines next step.
def route_confidence(state: TicketState):
    return "decide_escalation" if state["confidence"] == "high" else "human_review"


graph.add_conditional_edges(
    "confidence",
    route_confidence,
    {
        "decide_escalation": "decide_escalation",
        "human_review": "human_review"
    }
)


# If human corrected, return to classification to retry.
graph.add_edge("human_review", "classify")


# Route after escalation decision.
def route_severity(state: TicketState):
    return "escalate" if state["severity"] == "high" else "end"


graph.add_conditional_edges(
    "decide_escalation",
    route_severity,
    {
        "escalate": "escalate",
        "end": "end"
    }
)

# Escalation always triggers an email, then finish.
graph.add_edge("escalate", "send_mail")
graph.add_edge("send_mail", END)

# Compile workflow
app = graph.compile()



# --------------------------------------------------
# 6) Run Workflow
# --------------------------------------------------

initial_state: TicketState = {
    "ticket": "User cannot log in using I-User ID in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.",
    "retry_count": 0
}

final = app.invoke(initial_state)

print("\nFinal State:", final)

This what your output will look like -

Conclusion:

When you’re deciding between LangChain and LangGraph for your SAP AI workflows, ask yourself the following: 

How complex is my workflow? 

  • Linear and predictable? Use LangChain. 
  • Dynamic or with branching logic? Go for LangGraph. 

Do I need to persist state or approvals? 

  • Short-lived, single-session tasks (like a Q&A chatbot)? LangChain. 
  • Long-running, multi-step processes (like procurement)? LangGraph. 

What’s my optimization goal - speed or control? 

  • For rapid prototypes or proof-of-concepts, LangChain is your best friend. 
  • For production-ready, auditable, and orchestrated AI apps, LangGraph provides the structure you need. 

Start with what’s needed, keep it maintainable, and scale when your workflow truly calls for it. 
LangChain and LangGraph aren’t competitors, but rather act complementary in our AI projects. 

Happy Building and may your next AI project be both smart and sustainable.

Additional hands-on: 

http://community.sap.com/t5/artificial-intelligence-blogs-posts/hands-on-tutorial-building-an-ai-agent-with-human-in-the-loop-control/ba-p/14050267 

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/the-power-of-ai-agents-my-journey-with-langgraph/ba-p/14032724

entry.title: Agent系统基本功能组件
entry.content:
如果您对BTP感兴趣，BTP个人精选内容目录 | SAP Blogs 可能有更多你需要的内容

 

用过ChatGPT的朋友都有这样的体验：

好的时候：问它问题，回答很智能，像有个聪明助手在帮你

糟心的时候：

🤷‍♂️ 知识有限 - "抱歉，我不知道你们公司的具体情况"

🔄健忘症 - 聊了几轮就忘记前面说了什么

🚫只能聊天 - 不能帮你实际操作，比如发邮件、查数据库

📅信息过时 - 不知道最新的行业动态

🎭回答不稳定 - 有时专业有时随意，风格飘忽不定

⏰响应太慢 - 重复问题还要重新计算，浪费时间和钱

🔒没有权限控制 - 敏感信息谁都能问到

这些问题的根源是：单纯的LLM就像一个博学但与世隔绝的学者，空有知识却无法与现实世界深度连接。

 

而Agent系统就是为了解决这些痛点而生的！它把LLM包装成一个真正实用的智能助手，让AI不再只是"聊天工具"，而是能真正帮你办事的"智能员工"。

 

什么是Agent系统？

Agent系统 = LLM + 专业知识 + 实用工具 + 管理机制

简单来说：

LLM 是大脑，负责理解和思考

Agent系统 是完整的智能员工，不仅会思考，还有专业知识、能使用工具、受到管理约束

一个优秀的Agent系统除了本身的能力，还极大的依赖企业现有的IT基建

 

Agent系统的组件列表及用途

🤖核心智能

LLM接入点

😣用户痛点：想用AI但不知道选哪个模型，还担心被单一供应商绑定

解决方案：一站式接入多个LLM接口，支持灵活切换，并且可以为不同需求提供不同LLM

 

核心代理与代理库

😣用户痛点：想用一个LLM模型解决所有问题，结果什么都会一点，什么都不精通

解决方案：核心代理作为智能调度中枢，直接回答简单问题，复杂问题则寻求代理库中专业代理的帮助

核心代理像项目经理一样统筹全局，确保每个任务都找到最专业的"员工"

 

📚专业知识补强

业务语义库

😣用户痛点：AI不懂行业术语，答非所问，不知道最新的行业动态

解决方案：存储行业术语、业务规则、概念关系等专业知识

让AI说话像你们行业的专家

 

向量知识库

😣用户痛点：AI不知道你们公司的具体情况，回答都是网上的通用内容

解决方案：将你的文档转换为向量存储，支持智能检索

只需要上传企业文档，AI立刻变成专属顾问

 

文档库

😣用户痛点：AI的回答看似中肯，但没有依据，不知道信息来源是否可靠

解决方案：管理原始文档、图片、表格等多媒体资料

保证LLM引用的信息都能追溯到源文档

 

🛠️ 实际操作能力

工具库

😣用户痛点：AI只能聊天不能实际操作，比如发邮件、查数据库

解决方案：集成各种外部工具和API，如计算器、搜索引擎、数据库等

让AI真正连接现实世界，能操作各种系统

 

🎯交互体验优化

历史对话记忆库

😣用户痛点：AI健忘症严重，聊了几轮就忘记前面说了什么

解决方案：存储对话历史，维护完整上下文

像和老朋友聊天，越聊越默契

 

提示词管理

😣用户痛点：AI回答风格不稳定，有时专业有时随意，难以控制

解决方案：在用户输入之前添加一组指令，一起发送给LLM，精确控制行为

让AI始终保持你想要的专业形象和回答风格

 

对话入口

😣用户痛点：电脑办公，手机办公，工厂内办公需要不同交互方式，如果交互方式单一的化容易导致体验差

解决方案：根据不同场景提供不同交互方式，支持文本、语音等

降低使用门槛，为所有场景都提供Agent能力

 

⚡性能，成本，安全和治理

缓存提速插件

😣用户痛点：LLM响应太慢，重复问题还要重新计算，浪费时间和钱

解决方案：缓存LLM和各种库的常见查询和计算结果，避免重复处理

响应更快，成本更低，体验更好

 

LLM管理与评估

😣用户痛点：不知道不同模型各自适合什么场景，包括回答的质量，成本是否合理等

解决方案：为模型提供评估框架，来确定相同数据下不同模型的表现和成本

确保Agent稳定好用，花钱心里有数

 

身份与安全中心

😣用户痛点：担心数据泄露，敏感信息没有权限控制，谁都能问到

解决方案：完整的身份认证、权限管理和内容安全检查

放心使用，该看的能看，不该看的绝对保密

 

总结

看完这些组件，你会发现Agent系统就是针对开头提到的每个痛点都给出了解决方案：

✅知识不再有限 - 通过业务语义库，向量知识库掌握你的专业业务

✅告别健忘症 - 历史对话库让AI越聊越懂你

✅不只是聊天 - 工具库让AI能真正做事

✅信息永远最新 - 工具库提供实时数据

✅回答风格稳定 - 提示词管理确保专业形象

✅响应快成本低 - 缓存和监控优化性能

✅权限安全可控 - 完善的安全治理体系

Agent系统让AI真正从"聊天机器人"变成"智能员工"，从而能更加实际的产生价值

entry.title: Re: Username invalid for Real User Monitoring in SAP Clou...
entry.content:
Dear customer,

the user names are hashed in case that the user doesn't have the role to access the sensitive data. Only the user has the role of Real User Analyst Sensitive or Real User Analyst Administrator is able to see the real user names.

See https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-cloud-alm/operations/expert-portal/real-user-monitoring/run-details.html?anchorId=section_225976655_co

Best regards,
SAP Support

When I enable “Repeat for Each Data Item” on the main container that holds the invoice layout, Designer shows an error as soon as the item table is placed inside it. If the table is left outside, then only one table is printed for all 7 copies.

  • Copy 2 - Duplicate for Transporter

entry.title: Re: Do we need to scheudle a job for report PPH_MRP_SET_C...
entry.content: Yes, the report PPH_MRP_SET_CACHE often needs to be scheduled as a background job to keep the cache in sync. The Fiori apps (like Monitor External Requirements and Manage External Requirements) rely on cached data rather than real-time synchronization with classic transactions like MD04. Without scheduling, the cache can become outdated, which is why you saw the discrepancy until you ran the report manually

entry.title: Re: BRAND field in Material Master
entry.content:
Hi @Dinesh_158 ,

The new BRAND field in the Manage Product Master Data app (SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition) is part of the product’s General Data section. You can maintain values for it either directly in the Fiori app when creating or editing a product, or via the Product Master Data APIs (e.g., API_PRODUCT_SRV). To add values, you need to ensure the Brand ID (MARA-BRAND_ID) is enabled in your configuration and then populate it during product maintenance. To find the BRAND field open the manage Product Master Data app (Fiori ID: F1602). Navigate to a product record and go to the General Data tab. The BRAND field appears alongside other identifiers like product category and industry sector. Technically, it maps to the backend field MARA-BRAND_ID

You can add master records directly in the App. Use the Create Product or Edit Product option in the app. In the General Data section, enter the desired brand value in the BRAND field. Save the product record.

If you want to add with Product Master Data API (API_PRODUCT_SRV). Use a PUT or POST request to update product master records. Include the BRAND field in the payload under the A_Product entity.

Hope you got the idea how to do it. please confirm if you are able to resolve it

entry.title: Re: Freight condition based on PO quantity STO (conversion)
entry.content: SAP standard always prorates freight based on delivered quantity, even for absolute conditions. This is by design and cannot be changed in standard. If the business requires the PO-entered freight to remain fixed, you need either a header-based custom condition type, an enhancement in pricing logic, or manual freight posting at invoice level. Without one of these adjustments, the system will continue to redistribute freight during delivery creation

entry.title: Re: Space: Calculating size of unused LOB space
entry.content:
Using SUM( CAST( LENGTH( <lobcol> ) AS BIGINT )) to estimate the size of a LOB object is not precise since LOB values are store in blocks of size 1024 ^ N bytes and some LOB values are inlined. It is better to use the procedure LOB_ALLOC to investigate the contents of a LOB object. Pleases see the following blog for details:

LOB Administration in a Db2 LUW database - SAP Community

entry.title: Re: Is debit is '+' and credit is '-' is same in SAP SD &...
entry.content: The principle of debit and credit is consistent across SAP MM, SD, ECC, and S/4HANA. However, the way values are displayed (‘+’ or ‘-’) is not universal — it depends on the account type and the report layout. For example, a debit increases inventory in MM, receivables in SD, and expenses in FI, while a credit increases revenue or liabilities. So yes, the core rule applies across modules and versions, but the signs you see in reports may differ.

entry.title: why does the configuration activity 101073 only apply to company codes marked as CN?
entry.content:
What does this configuration activity "Activate Document Numbering for Company Code" (ID:101073) mean, and why does it only apply to company codes marked as CN, not others?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: why does the configuration activity 101073 only apply...
entry.content:
I wanted to clarify that this activity is specifically designed for localization purposes in China. As a result, it automatically associates with company codes marked as CN.

And you can use this configuration activity to activate the function of generating official document numbers for a company code.

  • If the Activate checkbox is selected.
    The function of generating ODN for a company code is activated. When a new accounting document is created for the given company code, the system automatically generates an official document number for that at the time of posting.
  • If the Post-Generate checkbox is selected.
    When a new accounting document is created for the given company code, there is no official document number generated. The system generates the official document number only when you run the Accounts Document Output - China app. It is recommended to use this option to generate official document numbers.
